justification: “Positive and negative affect were measured using the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS).”
The authors state that the PANAS “presents two sub-scales with 10 items each, one for positive affect … and another one for negative affect.”
“Mental health status was measured using the short form of the Depression, Anxiety and Stress Scale (DASS-21).” The depression sub-scale was specifically scored and reported.
The same sentence notes that DASS-21 includes an anxiety sub-scale, and anxiety scores and severity categories are later presented.
DASS-21 also contains a stress sub-scale; participants’ stress levels and cut-offs are reported in the results.
“State empathy was measured using the Measure of State Empathy (MSE) scale… three 3-item sub-scales to measure state levels of cognitive, affective, and compassionate empathy.”
The MSE description explicitly lists “affective (‘physically feeling the same way as another person is feeling’)” as one of its sub-scales.
The same paragraph notes a third sub-scale measuring “compassionate empathy (‘in-the-moment feelings of compassion, sympathy or concern’).”
“The psychological impact of COVID-19 was measured using the Impact of Event Scale-Revised (IES-R).”

Participants “were presented with the dictator game … participants would be allocated with 100 euros … They might give the stranger any sum of money,” a standard experimental paradigm for measuring altruism.
The survey “randomly allocated” participants to gain vs. loss versions of the Asian Disease or Financial Crisis problems, classic tasks used to assess framing-based choice biases.
Participants “were randomly presented with either the Switch or the Footbridge dilemma,” which differentiate utilitarian and deontological moral choices.

The survey “presented participants with 20 altruistic/egoistic moral dilemmas … Each dilemma offered a more altruistic and a more egoistic decision alternative,” allowing calculation of an altruism score.
